marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Letters of Benjamin Harrison (1726-1791), governor of Virginia, 1781-1784, relating to the importation of salt, 1783; the commission to regulate navigation on the Potomac River, 1785; a land grant to Robert Cunningham, 1782; and two typed copies of the will of Harrison.
James Harris was a Diana Mills (Buckingham County), Virginia, tobacco planter.
Letters of Harris concerning prices and marketing conditions at Richmond, Va.
Lawyer and judge, of Milledgeville (Baldwin County), Georgia.

Legal correspondence of the firm of Hansell and Harris, attorneys, from the 1820s; and family letters from the Hansell, Hall, and Harris families thereafter. Topics include the Civil War, relief work by the ladies of Milledgeville, and Sherman's march through the town. Included are letters of Joseph E. Brown, Civil War governor of Georgia, written during the late 1860s.
John Y. Harris was a Dinwiddie County, Virginia, attorney.

Business papers of Harris and his law partner, A.M. Organ; one item, 1875, concerns work on township roads and timber for a plank road. There are also letters by Harris' brother-in-law, J.M. Dennis, relating to Reconstruction economic and political conditions in the cotton belt, especially in South Carolina.
Levi Harris was a resident of Charlotte Court House, Virginia.
Letters from relatives living in various parts of Virginia, chiefly Buckingham County, concerning family news of farmers.
Isham G. Harris was a Tennessee senator, 1847-1848, member of U.S. Congress, 1849-1851, Tennessee governor, 1857- 1861, and U.S. senator, 1877-1897

Correspondence of Isham G. Harris. Included in the collection are a letter, 1861, from John H. Savage, volunteering to organize Tennessee for Confederate support; a letter from A.S. Curry, Trenton, Tennessee, applying for the directorship of a bank there; and a letter, 1891, from Harris to Ben W. Austin, concerning a letter of General Albert Sidney Johnston.
John D. Harris was a Confederate soldier from North Carolina.
Letters of a Confederate soldier, one written from the field.
E. M. Harris was a trader dealing in yarn, leather, and other items in Cartersville, Georgia. His wife was named Emma, and they had a child named Rosa. Another child was born in 1864.
Business correspondence of Harris; and a letter from his sister-in-law, Adaline A. Hollingsworth, concerning family matters, local news, prices, and provisions.
Charles J. Harris was a Union soldier, from Willett (Cortland County), New York.

Letters from Harris, a private, stationed in Virginia, Florida, and South Carolina, commenting on conditions in the South, his reactions to Copperhead activities, and his bitterness against John Wilkes Booth after Lincoln's death.
Joel Chandler Harris was an author and humorist, of Atlanta (Fulton County), Georgia.

Letters of Harris to Georgia Harrison Starke and Nora-Belle Starke, sister and niece respectively of James P. Harrison, editor of the Monroe Advertiser of Forsyth, Ga., and onetime employer of Harris. The letters give accounts of the vicissitudes of Harris' career as a newspaperman and contain occasional comment on his own literary works and those of his contemporaries. In one letter he mentions that his verses "To Nora Bell" have been pronounced "very fine" by Paul Hayne. Several earlier letters, of an introspective cast, give the author's own account of his character and personality. Included also is a letter of application, probably to Stilson Hutchins of the Washington (Ga.) Post, and a note to Miss Jeannette Gilder concerning his "Plough-Hands' Song."
Partially published in Julia C. Harris, "Life and Letters of Joel Chandler Harris" (New York, 1918).
Josiah Harris was a dealer in barrel staves in Thomasvllle, North Carolina.
Letters and accounts to Josiah Harris from the firm of Peters [Petus?] and Reed, which handled his staves.
Benjamin Harrison was an American politician and lawyer who served as the 23rd president of the United States from 1889 to 1893.

A brief note, 1888, by Benjamin Harrison to Charles Emory of Carthage, Jasper County, Missouri, concerning Harrison's unit in the Civil War, the 70th Regiment of Indiana Infantry; a printed copy of Harrison's inaugural address; and a printed souvenir distributed at Harrison's inaugural ball, 1889.
